In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Certainly! Here is a sample code for the `wrap_string` function in Julia:

```julia
function wrap_string(input_str::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(input_str)
    result = ""
    current_line_length = 0

    for word in words
        # Check if adding the word will exceed the text_width
        if current_line_length + length(word) > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        result *= "$word "
        current_line_length += length(word) + 1
    end

    return result
end

# Example
input_text = "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(input_text, 20)
println(wrapped_text)
```

This code defines a function called `wrap_string` that takes an input string and an optional `text_width` parameter. The function splits the input string into words, and adds a newline character whenever the current line length exceeds the specified `text_width`.

The example provided wraps the input text at a width of 20 characters. You can customize the input text and text width as needed.
